rComments: I had Professor Radforth for HIS312 & HIS313. His lectures were perceived as bland to many of my friends, however, I thoroughly enjoyed the way he teaches (decent info on slides, majority taught by what he says). He is obviously very intelligent, and appreciates those who go to his office hours. Absolute unit, and I wish him the best in retirement.
Dr. Radforth is a wonderful professor. He is a caring, helpful, and fair grader. Unlike other professors, Dr. Radforth wants you to succeed and is there for you.  A+.

HORRIBLE. I love Canadian history and he made me hate what he taught. If it was not for me teaching myself the topics through extra research, I would not have passes. He is very dry when it comes to his lectures. The assignments were very easy though. One thing he did well was assignments
Lectures were a bit dry. Overall, easy to follow. Lectures draw heavily from readings and are almost a regurgitation

Cdn HIS Major, I've taken all his courses and like his style.  Syllabus is crystal clear and he sticks to it.  There are no surprises and you know exactly what to study for.  His exams match the syllabus meticulously.
Amazing Prof! Take evry class you can from him if you love Canadian History!

Good professor. The seminar got a bit dry, but he was fairly good at directing discussion considering how quiet the whole class was. The readings were also somewhat dry, though there was usually at least one interesting reading each week. Overall not the most interesting professor, but he marked fairly and was both helpful and clear.

To be honest, I found him to be a rather boring lecturer. He's obviously very knowledgeable about the subject and loves it, but his teaching style is very old-fashioned. I wish the course had been more challenging. Could've been a 2nd yr course in my opinion. Overall, it was an alright learning experience.

Great lecturer, but his style can be pretty dry. Course was not the least bit challenging though. It's an easy course but since I'm very interested in the material I was expecting more in-depth analytical work throughout. Still, it's a good introduction course to Canadian immigration history.

Radforth is a talented lecturer. He speaks quickly but clearly and concisely. He is very well organized. We used one textbook, but the readings were quite interesting as they were generally well-written articles. His TAs in Fall 2009 marked well, providing useful feedback on papers. He made the course interesting and enjoyable, and I learned a lot.

I highly recommend the course HIS 313 - Canadian Labour History. Radforth is an excellent lecturer - he knows his topics inside out. Only one book is used and the readings are short,engaging and very manageable to stay on top of. He is a fair marker and if you do your readings and make an effort you can do well.
Radforth was a very good Prof, one of the best at U of T. Lectures were clear however i found his t.a's marked rather harsh
great prof, knows his stuff, classes can get a bit boring and he can run off on tangents but its worth it, loved every minute of the class

Radforth was an interesting prof, he was knowledgeable and very approachable. The class could get boring over time but what class isn't? Overall I say take this class if the topic interests you, if not you may be insanely bored.
Very nice guy and helpful. However, lectures were not stunning and I found it very difficult to get excited about going to class.

This course turned out to be completely different from how I thought. It was very slow and often boring. He added little insight and he asked questions on the readings,while we answered.The only saving grace is that it was fairly easy so you can do well if you do your readings and speak up in class.
Labour history background - pays too much attention to tests and memory work from the readings, but really loves his subject matter and makes lectures interesting!
